animalOfTheDay.name: stoat
facts: Stoats are small but fierce predators that can take down prey much larger than themselves.
In cold climates, they turn white in winter and are called ermine.
Stoats perform a hypnotic 'dance' to confuse prey before attacking.
They are excellent climbers and swimmers, hunting in trees and water.

calendar.name: spider
facts: Spiders are not insects; they are arachnids, with eight legs and two body segments.
The venom of most spiders is harmless to humans, with only a few species being dangerous.
All spiders produce silk, but not all spiders spin webs to catch prey.
Some spiders can 'balloon' by releasing silk threads to catch the wind and travel long distances.

calendar.name: squid
facts: The giant squid is the largest invertebrate, with eyes the size of dinner plates.
Some squid species can 'fly' by propelling themselves out of the water and gliding for short distances.
They can change color rapidly to communicate or camouflage, using specialized cells called chromatophores.
Squid have three hearts: two pump blood to the gills, and one pumps it to the rest of the body.

calendar.name: squirrel
facts: Squirrels communicate with each other using tail flicking and vocalizations.
Some species of squirrels can leap up to 20 feet between trees.
They can rotate their ankles 180 degrees to climb down trees headfirst.
Squirrels plant thousands of trees each year by forgetting where they buried their acorns.

calendar.name: starfish
facts: Starfish are not fish; they are echinoderms, related to sea urchins and sand dollars.
Starfish have no brain or blood; instead, they use a water vascular system to move their tube feet.
There are over 2,000 species of starfish, found in all the world's oceans.
They can regenerate lost arms, and some species can even regrow an entire body from a single arm.

calendar.name: stick insect
facts: They can regenerate lost limbs when they molt.
Stick insects are among the longest insects, with some species reaching over 2 feet in length.
Stick insects are masters of camouflage, resembling twigs or leaves.
Some species can reproduce without males through parthenogenesis.

calendar.name: stingray
facts: They use electroreceptors to detect the electrical signals of prey hidden in the sand.
Stingrays 'fly' through the water by flapping their pectoral fins like wings.
Their stingers are modified scales and can deliver venom, but they only use them in self-defense.
Stingrays are closely related to sharks and have skeletons made of cartilage, not bone.

calendar.name: stoat
facts: Stoats perform a hypnotic 'dance' to confuse prey before attacking.
They are excellent climbers and swimmers, hunting in trees and water.
In cold climates, they turn white in winter and are called ermine.
Stoats are small but fierce predators that can take down prey much larger than themselves.

randomAnimals.name: sand dollar
facts: Sand dollars are flat sea urchins that live on the ocean floor.
They feed by filtering tiny particles of food from the sand using their tube feet.
The five-petal pattern seen on dead sand dollars is actually their skeletal structure.
When alive, they are covered in tiny, velvety spines that help them move and feed.

randomAnimals.name: zorse
facts: A zorse is a hybrid of a male zebra and a female horse, resulting in an animal with a horse-like appearance with zebra stripes.
These are bred animals and do not occur naturally in the wild.
Like mules, zorses are usually sterile, meaning they cannot have their own offspring.
Their stripes are usually less distinct than those of zebras and often appear only on their legs and neck.

randomAnimals.name: binturong
facts: Their fur is coarse and dark, and long whiskers help them navigate in the dark.
They have prehensile tails that serve as a 'fifth limb' for moving through trees.
They are nocturnal and omnivorous, feeding on fruits, small mammals, birds, and eggs.
Binturongs, also known as bearcats, are mammals from Southeast Asia that smell like buttery popcorn.
